pros: I honestly can't give any good pros about UW Health, other than I had friendly coworkers inside my own team.
cons: The IS department is poorly ran. Directors who have little to no technical experience don't listen to their staff, and then wonder why things run poorly. There is combativeness between departments that led to an awful work experience when you need to work with other groups. I dreaded having to work with other departments at times because of how unwilling to help, and how unfriendly some of the staff were. Being on-call was one of the worst parts about the job, even if it was a handful of times per year. Getting paged for the most benign things and getting woken up multiple times per night for alerts that would clear themselves was frustrating. You also get paged by other departments frequently who decide to skirt around change control requirements and do upgrades that break things in the middle of the night. There was no work/life balance due to the amount of production-affecting issues that happened constantly. UW Health loves asking for donations and your time volunteering, yet the CEO, Alan Kaplan, makes a multi-million dollar salary and getting 15%+ a year raises.

cons:
The execution of the stated commitments of the organization is inconsistent. It appears that there are some areas that excel. But there are many areas and programs that are allowed to fester in unhealthy workplace culture and consistently deprioritize the wellbeing of staff.

Very poor parental leave policies. One paid week. Need to use any/all accrued PTO to cover any additional time. Staff return to work before they are ready, before baby/child is ready, just to prevent financial crisis. review_title: If you care about your career you wont stay long
pros:
WRS is one of the best in the country. 

There is an attempt to maintain a positive environment for the sake of patients.

Healthcare in general tends to collects high performers that try hard to make a difference.

There are some great individual working teams who care about each other but who are siloed away from each other.

The overall mission is noble and creates engagement. We have helped countless people in spite of other issues.
cons:
The positivity is only for the sake of patients. Employees as a whole are miserable.
High performance is discouraged. The former "performance management"
system was done away with after too many people complained that every employee regardless of merit was given the same performance score as a way to save money. Ergo, high performance is actively discouraged. 

The plethora of horrible managers can basically do what they will based on their personal feelings to their reports with no way for reports to defend themselves from the many slimy, often incompetent managers. 
I've seen many very experienced people be hired and then treated as a threat or ignored until they either quit or get fired for simply performing at their level of competence and experience. The turnover in some non clinical departments is mind boggling. Many managers have been hired not for their leadership aptitudes like sound judgement or lack of insecurity, 
or technical competence but for their ability to blow smoke. There have been a couple notable exceptions who almost immediately became jaded and looked for a way to escape their own direct manager. 
I've never seen so many senior employees step down from their roles in frustration. It truly is a sight to behold. 

Employees are clearly treated as dollars only. There is no concern in some non clinical departments for employee retention, not through recognition, employee development like mentoring or training, no concern at all if someone leaves other than the obligatory lip service (after notice of resignation not before) to keep up appearances. No action taken to retain any employee unless there is a specific dollar amount for training attached to that employee and then it's only as a knee-jerk reaction. 
There is no attempt at employee development in many departments.

In departments where it's critical to retain experienced employees for the safety of the organization, the pattern has been to hire people who have literally had no other job before one where experience should be the baseline. 
Every other experienced person leaves as soon as they can, creating and endless cycle that managers, lacking in any proactivity and a great many necessary aptitudes cannot address. 
It takes a departmental staffing crisis to create enough signal to affect basic changes in management operations and employee treatment and that signal has to get to upper levels in the org for the requirement to improve even a little gets back to the department. 

Being attached to a government institution and with part of the org being a 'state' entity, there is always a toxic stew of progressive box-checking politics which makes an already difficult environment much worse. Every one is supposed to be respected as an individual, unless you can check one of those boxes, then you quickly realize that not all are respected the same from the view of the org regardless of how great interactions between co-workers may be and that reflects in management decision making.

pros: Supports phenomenal work/life balance.  Compensation and benefits are top notch.
cons:
Within the past year, the trend seems to slowly take away from employees actually being able to be progressive, proactive and just get work done, management wants to literally know every single thing that is happening.  You have to wait months just to get simple changes done and you have to wait for one individual to bless you to work.  Micromanaging every single decision has become the norm, and a lot of individuals aren't technically competent enough to be making these decisions.  

Teams don't communicate.  Teams refuse to work together.  Teams roadblock each other as much as possible.  Ego reigns and end user/physicians/patients suffer.  

Also, as much as they say they want to facilitate learning, this is only for selected people that have favor in the eyes of whatever director likes them.  There are no pathways for promotion, no pathways for education to help your career goals and no discussions about where they are in the process.  It's been a year since we heard they might be creating new jobs/titles for individuals who want to either be technical or managerial and it was six months ago they were supposed to let us know what those were.  

Also, loyalty matters little.  You could be a stellar employee for years but they will totally hire outside of UW Health for a position you are totally qualified for.

job_title: Medical Coding Specialist in Madison, WI
pros: Work independently, nice environment to work in, a respectful atmosphere, great benefits.
cons: Rigid productivity requirement. Not adjusted to the difficulty level of individual jobs. I don't believe there should be a blanket rate for all  jobs. My job encompassed many more requirements than the average coder encounters. The learning curve was not taken into consideration. The department I was in lost 3 employees in the same position in less than a year. From what I have observed, this appears to be an across the board problem with this particular corporation. There appears to be preconceived standardizations that don't always meet the reality of each individual job.

pros:
The department is great to work in. I was a recent college graduate at UW-Madison and I could not have been put in a better place. Graduating from the fine institution I was expecting to make almost 6 figures a year. While no courses at UW actually prepared me for the real world, my expectations turned into goals of the future as I needed to create my solid stepping stone in order to advance through post grad and as a working professional. 
1) Working for UW-Health Admissions is interesting especially if you are looking to move towards insurance or healthcare administration this place is right. However, more importantly if you are a recent college graduate, this place will provide the work experience needed considering that it will be professional work experience. 
2)The staff in admissions is what makes the department the best. Very supportive and always on the verge of your best interest especially PROMOTION FROM WITHIN!!!
3) The pay is very nice especially the vacation days which you get your first day of work!
4) The flexibility of calling off is amazing (first come first served)
5) Job Security
cons: You deal with patients and you will get the tip of the tongue at a patients most vulnerable time. Stay calm and understand with empathy!

review_title: Secure place to work but wages stink
job_title: Blue Collar Department Worker in Madison, WI
pros: I like my job and like the people I work with.
cons: Wages are not good. After ten years I've finally hit $13.00 an hour. Middle managment has no clue what's going on in their departments and they never listen to their employees as to better ways to get the job done. The employees are the frontline workers and we do the job but managment thinks they know more about our job than we do. There's no schedule, planning or organizing in my department. How do you expect to serve over 6000 people with no form of organizing?

pros: Low insurance rates. Benefits for 401k, life insurance, and tuition reimbursement are good. Some of the supervisors are good to work with.
cons: Management not in touch with employees. Manager makes excuses for all the employees leaving. HR received many complaints from several staff but same issues continue. Bully environment, staff being yelled at, verbal abuse allowed. Manager wondering why the morale is so low.

job_title: Resident Physician in Eau Claire, WI
pros: Cold climate, so little chance of catching malaria.  Inexpensive housing and cost of living versus pay.  Easy to get hired here.
cons: Recommends workers go to their psychiatrist.  They consider this area to be "Scandinavian," but it really means there is no tolerance for urban and international personalities.  Sent Spanish worker for English classes.  Teaches physicians to be overly critical of patients.  Many patients are considered to seek drugs.  Workers who speak less are considered more intelligent than those who speak more.  Asking for clarification reveals weakness.  Instead, ask your overworked fellow workers.  Don't use the dictation service even though it's available.  It costs them money and they don't like it.  Don't use the dictation program they give you.  It will turn words like "newborn" into "mongolian spot" or whatever.  You won't catch it and you'll get in trouble.  Get last year's in-service board exam before showing up and review it.  Lots of questions will be the same.  They give you that test right away.  It can make you look bad if you don't do good.  They say it's better if you don't study for it but that's not so true.

review_title: Great work environment, but management wants the good of the best RN for free...
pros: Great work envirnonment. Critical care unit is well supplied, well staffed, professional and employs best practices. Respect from MDs on the unit and true autonomy in practice. Culture of excellence.
cons:
Cannot read emails during contract negotiations because it is too upsetting to hear about the hospital management trying to cut critical items from nursing. 
Magnet status, Best nursing quality per ANA, Stroke center, etc, yet pay, benefits, etc being threatened by management, Please dont advertise how excellent the nursing is in one breath, them turn and try to cut pay and benefits in the next!

Lift issues are ignored although turning patients every 2 hours is required, and nurses are constantly injuring themselves. 
Computer charting is soooo redundant, with dozens of required flowsheets per hour, that RN, have lost alot of bedside time.
"Quality Assurance" initiatives undermined by discipline overlapping, as in lab errors.
No overtime allowed, so any minutes over 12 are deducted from vaca or floating holiday time.

pros: Fair treatment, good benefits, coworkers can be excellent but it is hit-or-miss depending on:  the department you are working in, your managing clinician, your scheduler.
cons: Unless you're a manager or a physician, your job is very robotic.  You will be doing more or less the same exact thing every day you work.  There may be an unexpected surprise along the way but...it's really just the same ol' thang with a different flavor put on top.  There is little recognition for performance.  If you are efficient, your reward will just be picking up the slack for others around you.  Finally, if you are spending time among nurses, brace yourself (heavily) for endless banter about upcoming weddings and babies.  It's like working among housewives who happened to get a job.

review_title: Coworkers are great, leadership needs work
pros: Good pay for a 4-year degree, 1.5x pay for overtime and picking up. My manager is great and tries to fight for us where and when she can.
cons: Many decisions are made from top down, individuals and managers have little power because everything has to go through the higher-ups. Matching for your 401k takes 5 YEARS to get vested, and this is prorated based on your FTE. This alone has felt like a ransom to get me to continue to work there. Tuition reimbursement used to be excellent, but a few years ago they cut reimbursement by a very large amount, and now it's comparable to every other health care agency around.

job_title: Sterile Processing Technician in Madison, WI
pros: Benefits are pretty good. Often times promotions come from within.
cons: Recently raised cost for several things. Gave employees a raise to offset the costs. Their idea of offsetting the cost is 6000 dollars less in my pocket after another year of good hard work. Not too many people are happy with that. Salaries don't match up to competition in the area and good employees are dropping like flies

pros:
Awesome team work between nurses and support staff
Great pay
Decent work load
Great hours(12hr shifts)
Overtime available
Free bus pass for the duration of your employment
UWHC is a great place to work-but only if you're on the right unit(s)
Rarely ran out of supplies
cons:
TERRIBLE MANAGER!!!
Difficult patients/patient load at times
Made to feel incompetent, and belittled
Singled out and hunted if manager didn't like you or you disagreed with her
Way too much favoritism
Unless you park off-site and take the bus, parking is HORRENDOUS to pay for, employees should NEVER have to pay to come to work

review_title: They don’t care about your wellbeing
pros: The work is interesting and challenging.
cons:
I have to work 55 hours a week. When I break my salary down, I might as well serve in a staff position. The culture is such that you have to work so much and you are judged if you want a work life balance.

They are prioritizing physician well being and providing them paid time off for paternity/maternity leave up to $30,000. The management team isn’t provided anything guaranteed- you must save your time.

review_title: It can be rewarding, but too many senior administrators who are easily threatened and limited in the competence.
pros: They treat you well. Pay is good (I imagine in some areas they are very competitive, in others not so much). The ethic and missions are terrific There are some great leaders and staff.
cons: Very limited opportunities for career advancement. This is a physician dominated and controlled organization, so non-physicians are not as highly valued. While this is to be expected, too often physicians are placed in senior administrative positions and have limited skill sets outside of their medical training.

review_title: Not what it used to be
pros: Pay is only ok, but is getting worse. WRS and benefits are still great, despite the cut applied with Act 10.  Employees tend to be quality individuals, but the environment seems to be almost sterile.
cons: Treatment of employees is sub-par, but not horrible either.   Zero worker protection with the unions gone.  I recommend getting into a classified state of Wisconsin position if you want job security.

pros: I was working at the American Center location which is the newer, advanced hospital and wellness center. The place is clean and beautiful! The small group of dietitians that work here are supportive and willing to help another out. I enjoyed my coworkers; everyone treats each other with dignity and respect. My manager made himself available to talk with and always gave a listening ear. I had the opportunity to fill in at the other hospitals associated with UW Hospitals and Clinics, but the teamwork and communication here is far superior. I left the position because of a move.
cons: Some issues with CBORD digital menu system that could take away from dietitian's other tasks for the day. Hours really fluctuated (though pay rate per hour was good), so I decided pick up another part time job to supplement income (manager was cool about it).

review_title: A good couple of years as a temp employee.
pros:
Good benefits for full-timers. I was full-time but on a temporary, seasonal basis, so I didn't get those benefits. 

Coworkers are generally friendly. Pay is competitive, but not amazing. They rarely ever want you putting in more than 40h/week to pay overtime, so it offers a good work/life balance.
cons: Office gossip can get bad. Just starting off, the benefits/vacation/salary aren't that great - it takes time to move up the ranks. There really isn't any way to fast-track this movement... you get an annual review and that's pretty much your only opportunity to demonstrate what you're worth and demand more for your abilities.

pros: I worked here as an undergrad and was hired on as a full-time employee after graduation. It is a great job for what it is. The pay is reasonable right out of school. The benefits are standard since you work for the state. Vacation, sick leave, and personal time are awesome! You get a lot of time and all the vacation rolls over. HR always seems to want to help and generally people are nice and helpful.
cons: You are part of a very, very large institution, so you have to be your own advocate if you are in need of anything. The office culture depends on what department and division you work in. The first division I worked in felt like a big family and the second one felt like a bunch of middle-school cliques.

pros: Overall I feel that UWHC was an excellent place to work and grow as a nurse clinician.  The benefits, salary and opportunities for growth were good.  I would recommend UWHC to a fellow nurse!
cons: I feel that too much was expected by upper management of RNs, without knowing the reality of what it means to provide care at the bedside.  The culture of being a bedside nurse at UWHC is filled with unprofessional gossiping and lack of support by fellow RNs.

review_title: Be careful of applying to mental health positions
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Madison, WI

review_title: Overall a good place to work
job_title: Systems Analyst In the IT Department in Madison, WI
pros: Benefits, stimulating environment, lots of great co workers.  Focus on promoting from within.  Lots of interesting projects and are always new things to be learned.
cons: Wish there were part time opportunities, not all full time .   They recently eliminated flex time and seem to be less interested in fostering a positive work-life balance compared to previous years....so they seem less interested than they used to be in retaining experienced staff.  The ways promotions were handled was inconsistent.  Not much upward mobility unless you want to be in management.  Often involved in projects that require a lot of extra hours...need to assert boundaries to not get caught up working lots of extra hours.

pros: The Health benefits and 401k are great. The main admin AOB building is really nice.
cons: Here is just a small list of issues. Management had no idea what their employees actually do. The workload vs staffing level has gotten much worse. They can't hire for positions that have been vacant for a year. No a family place. Everyone looks out for them selfs. This reorganization is a load of crap that was not discussed with the employees. The CTO is an unprofessional person and would yell at you in front of people.

review_title: Your Experience Depends on your Manager
job_title: Clinical Systems Analyst in Madison, WI
pros: Benefits, free parking (dependent upon location), great group of co-workers, somewhat flexible hours.
cons: Management.  There is way too much management, and depending upon who you report to, your experience working for UW can be great or terrible - there really is no in between.  I spent far too long working for awful management, and no matter how much proof and documentation of harassment you give to HR or to your managers' superior, NOTHING changes.  I am lucky to work for an excellent manager now who is very much involved with his team and forming a strong community.

pros: Residency program, great team at The American Center, state benefits, pay
cons: Top down management, "shared governance" leaves more to be desired, more worried about cost than patient and staff satisfaction, often worked understaffed. You will lose all accrued sick time if you resign and don't return to the organization within one year.

job_title: Student Lab Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: This job provided a great place to build a foundation for a job after college, also an interesting work environment that exposes you to a variety of laboratory techniques; there is the opportunity for collaboration with research professionals. The hours for this job were very flexible, and there was always something to do.
cons: You will have to engage in some repetitive tasks: data entry, media making, specimen processing; co-workers sometimes not reliable

pros:
Schedule - Typically five 8hr shifts, Mon-Fri, Weekend call every other month, Weekday call once per week.
Tuition Reimbursement at 100% if you are .6FTE or higher (Will change in June 2014)
Surgeons are friendly and fun to work with for the most part
cons: RNs have little to no say in practice/policy changes within the Surgical Services department. Call pay is decreasing to only $2.25/hr and getting paid for a minimum of 3hrs (starting in June). Limited availability to take vacation. Management doesn't support staff who "speak out" they are labeled as "trouble makers" and treated with a threatening attitude. Many changes taking place in June 2014 including a 6.5% decrease in pay.

review_title: Fairly progressive hospital with large regional footprint, needs to move towards innovation and overcome politics.
job_title: Health Systems Engineer in Madison, WI
pros: Great people. Everyone is very helpful, friendly and patient centered. Fairly progressive with technology, using engineers and improvement strategies.
cons: Due to the friendly culture, things are swept under the rug and people hold their tongue rather than express concerns directly.

review_title: Excellent specialists, employees not a priority
pros: Excellent, caring & skilled service providers, comprehensive care, decent vacation and sick leave.
cons: Employees and their concerns are not priority for the bureaucracy of the hospital business. There are high expectations with little room for flexibility. Depending on the level of management the culture can be toxic. Too much expected of providers outside of direct patient care and the burden keeps increasing which leads to poor patient care and burnout.

pros: Nice facility in middle of nowhere west Madison. If you’re old, like >55 you’re in the right place.
cons: Can’t change process or thoughts to save themselves. Miserable managers. Incompetent decision making. Zero incentive to do more than minimum because you won’t be rewarded for hard work.  If you enjoy working in a 1970’s IBM you’re in the right spot.  20-40 year olds need not apply.  This place will suck the life from anyone energetic, creative or motivated.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Most of my co- workers were great, however the doctor I worked under was a complete jerk. It's dumb that they pay their schedulers the same as a Medical Assistant with 3 years of experience. That's the Union of course, although I am not sure what "the Union" does for you. I wasn't given the option to transfer when I informed them of my resignation. Whatever I FOUND A BETTER JOB the next day that pays what I should be paid.
cons: Parking, MA's are treated like crap, no room for growth.

review_title: A Company Worth Growing in over Time
pros:
-Fair Compensation and Excellent Benefits (I started with more vacation time than my mom has currently working at Verizon, and that doesn't even include sick leave)

-Opportunities for Advancement are in no shortage

-Great Entry Level Jobs for college graduates whether clinical or non-clinical

-Not for Profit 501-C3 (which means your employment qualifies for the federal Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program)
cons: -parking, Parking, PARKING! Parking is very limited and you will most likely have to pay to park in a surrounding lot (It should be noted though that you do get a free bus pass each year)

job_title: Prefer Not To Say in Madison, WI
pros: WRS that is it if you can stand to work there to actually get it.
cons: LEADERSHIP is HIGHLY unqualified for their roles, most of them have slept their way to the top, or intimidate everyone to get where they are in their incompetent unqualified roles.  If you know more than your superiors about anything, they create "fake" evidence to fire you. It is not the prestigious place it once was, very sad and leadership knows it ,which is why they are fighting the nurses union at every cost. GO ANYWHERE ELSE

review_title: UW - A great place to train
pros: Extremely positive working environment. Respectful coworkers who work as a team to put patient care first. There is an emphasis on universal precautions,improving infection control measures an.
cons:
Parking is expensive, and can be far away from clinical buildings in some locations. Outside parking can present a problem in the winter because of snow and ice accumulations on cars.
Management in the mid 1990s was greedy and kept nursing understaffed to cut costs. This is not a problem now. Excellent CEO emeritus and new CEO, Donna Bahensky working to maintain a positive working environment.

job_title: Emergency Department Technician (EDT) in Madison, WI
pros: Good pay, good benefits, Unlimited amounts of knowledge available, You will see things that you can only see at a Level I trauma center.
cons: Pay "equality" - EMT-B's with 15 years of experience are paid the same as Paramedics with 15 years of experience, RN's receive multiple pay differentials that aren't available to EDT's (ex: call in pay, off weekend pay, off shift pay); Safety - EDT's and other EDC's are required to sit out in the waiting room with no protective barrier regardless of multiple safety incidences. It has been brought up to management situation still remains the same; Overworked - RN's abuse the EDT's in regards to doing there work while they sit and socialize then complain when there are no EDT's and they have "too much work to do"; "Tuition Reimbursement"- UW Health's policy to reimburse education that directly relates to position with UW Health. If you are a EMT looking for a Paramedic education, UW Health won't provide it because EMTs and Paramedics are viewed as equals; High management turnover in the ED; Paramedics can't use any of their skills even though they're licensed to do so, but start IVs, because it isn't in the EDT job description, but they will train EMT-B's to start IV's even though they aren't licensed to do so because it is in the EDT job description; Department is never fully staffed, Can't keep up with the high turnover (RNs and EDTs); Management never asks for input of any ED staff. Decisions are just made no mater the result; Unless you are an RN, you will never be viewed as an equal member of the team until it is convenient for the department; "Continuing Education" - UWED doesn't reimburse any expenses required to maintain you licensure (i.e. refreshers/CEUs), but they will for RN's; Overall fear for job security.

pros: Even thought the hospital is a big place, after a while you will get to know most staff that you come to contact with.  Most staff are great to work with, everyone is friendly and professional.
cons: Because it is a big place to work at, management cannot micro managed employees.  There are employees that take advantage of this and didnt get their work done as it should be.

review_title: It used to be a great place to work
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Madison, WI
pros:
- Great health insurance

- Average wages

- Decent benefits package
cons:
- The managers are useless and say everything is "above their head."

- The upper level management only seems to care about making money and not about employees or even patients for that matter.

- The amount of policies and the policies themselves are ridiculous.

- HR either doesn't respond at all or responds but isn't able to answer your questions/concerns.

- Pay raises are hard to come by, and a decent raise is almost impossible to get.

- The burnout rate is high and there is no work/life balance. Employees are extremely overworked and underappreciated.

review_title: Decent overall company to work for.
pros: Wonderful coworkers and great doctors. Good job satisfaction. Family type of atmosphere with other staff that promoted good friendships and lasting relations.
cons: Too much micro managing from superiors that stifled innovation and growth. A good old boys club mentality and too many of the managers appeared to be still in their cliques from High School.

review_title: A dynamic dedicated health care organization
pros: For such a large complex organization it feels like home.  Staff are highly skilled, and driven to do good work for the benefit of the patients.  It is a workplace which instills pride because of the ground breaking work that is done there every day.  I see people at all levels strive to provide or contribute to the positive experience of patients and families.
cons: It is an overly complex organization which should move towards integration of it's 3 entities for the benefit of the patients, staff and community.

pros: Great place to work! Everyone is helpful and it is a great place to start off a nursing career. It is a teaching hospital as well and offers tuition reimbursement. I started in the nurse residency program which is accredited and extremely competitive. If you are able to get a spot in the program cherish it because it is phenomenal. Best hospital in the state!
cons: Constantly changing policies and procedures, often short on staff, the normal every other weekend shift which you should already be aware of if you are in the healthcare field.

pros:
-Competitive Pay (As Long As You NEGOTIATE)
-Great benefits; Medical, Vision & Dental
-Wisconsin Retirement System
cons:
-Management/Leadership
-Lack Of Accountability
-No Consistency
-Lied About Being Able To Transfer Shifts

pros: Academic rich environment which is a pro
cons: Poor Salary. Poor work home balance, no union and the management are aggressive and autocratic I was a number not a person there was nothing holistic about HR department. Senior leaders in the ED are ARROGANT a barrier and nothing is done about them, poor communication and lack of compassion to their employees. Look at other hospitals first

review_title: Frustrating trying to get time off that has been earned when there is not enough coverage for vacations.
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Madison, WI
pros: Great people to work with, opportunity to make a difference in someone's life through better health care and education.
cons: Mid-level management not always as professional as I have been accustomed to in past work experiences.  Difficult to get clear direction on expectations, depends on whom you are talking with at the moment.

pros: Great hours and great benefits. It can be quite rewarding to help otherwise under-served populations. Patients are often very happy to be able to be seen and to have their medical needs attended to.
cons: Company is quite large and employees may feel lost in the shuffle. Patients can be quite rude, especially when they have great medical needs. Staff can be quite rude to patients.

review_title: Great place to work though management can vary in levels of competence depending on the department
pros:
Good pay and great benefits
Great people to work with overall
many learning and educational opportunities available to those who wish to take advantage of them
cons:
Department managers and supervisors need to be more engaged with their staff
Parking fees are exorbitant on the university's lots but that's not the hospital's fault

pros: Professional environment, research oriented, smart motivated people, fair compensation, staff strive to be patient centered.
cons: Slow to make positive change, complex environment for patients to navigate.  Patient's treated as parts vs whole person.

pros: Well known teaching facilities that are great. Awesome learning setting and great state of the art equipment to aid in your learning.
cons: Generally the pay scale is well below the market. A recent market review was done and some long term employees won't get a raise and people that have been with company 5+years aren't close to the midpoint on the pay scale.

review_title: Organization is good, management not so much
pros: Good benefits, competitive pay, clean environment, cafeteria options, constant coffee (with donation).
cons: No training, leadership are friends first, leadership not organized and changes mind all the time, my specific leader was rude and condescending to staff who was under them as well as other teams, high turnover

job_title: Pharmacy Technician/Intern Pharmacist in Madison, WI
pros: look good on resume for pharmacy school applicants.
cons: very inflexible schedule and low pay. Since most pharm techs are college pre-pharm student, school is the most important part yet managers don't not accommodate your exam schedule with work AT ALL! It makes it almost impossible to balance the two. Thus, the turn-over rate is super super high, which means you will be working with new/inexperienced co-workers all the time and its very inefficient.

pros: Flexible schedules, employee learning and development opportunities, culture of research and teaching, specialty nationally renowned doctors
cons: Parking and fees, non-competitive salaries or wages (especially for non-RN positions) and HR department in general, outdated facilities, too many committees without clear direction- takes forever to get a decision made

review_title: Used to be a good place to work
pros: Given opportunities to advance. Good pay, descent benefits, flexible hours.
cons: Management doesn't care about anything but the numbers. Required overtime due to poor decision making. HR is non-existent and protective of management. Lots of micromanaging and promoted managers that suck at management/no previous experience. No employee recognition whatsoever. Very fake management.

review_title: great place for health care research
pros: Benefits are good to work in the health care companies. Experiences collaborating with scientists and doctors to help learning new things quickly.
cons: Senior management needs to be more stable. It may get quite cold in winter, sometimes takes half an hour to dig car out of the snow, so please get an underground parking while living in Madison if possible. Heavy constructions in the UW hospitals area at the present.

pros: Great patients and a decent benefit package. Good Hours.
cons: Too much gossip and favortism. Coworkers worry too much about other employees and not the patients. The manager has rules that only apply to certain people. There is one employee who wears clothes that shows her butt and is very rude to patients and other employees. She is one of the managers "favorites". The providers get very cranky and will either look at you like you are stupid, throw a tantrum and stomp away, and other things. You are expected to do the work of 3 people and maintain a positive attitude at all times.

pros: Health insurance and retirement package
cons:
-Limited room for transfers or advancement
-Terrible Management
-As a provider, I still have to interact with this company and have never dealt with ruder people who think they are better than you when trying to facilitate patient care
-Poor access to care-if you can wait weeks or months, than you may get a visit 
-They are so far in debt because of constant construction that they are looking at employee layoffs
-I've never worked anywhere where management felt so threatened by people doing advanced certifications or degrees

review_title: Not the place it use to be
pros: Co-workers are supportive and helpful.
cons: The environment has become toxic in the last two years with the new CEO and his management picks.  The top levels have ballooned while the workers are being asked to do more work with fewer people and resources every day.  Management seems to have adopted an attitude that "beatings will continue until morale improves."  Benefits are being cut back as yet another cost saving measure.

pros: free to work on your own with little supervision, can set your own work hours within a certain degree.
cons: supervisor does not know what the employees do so evaluations are always "avg". Over 3 years I have had trouble getting out of this department and into something more suited for my degree.

pros:
Annual Raises, benefits very good compared to other companies.
Good training, good management (at my site at least).
I do feel like a valued employee.
cons: I'm very fortunate to have good management at the clinic I work at, but I don't think this is the case everywhere.

review_title: Good place to work if you are a specialist
pros: They offer very good benefits. There is also tuition reimbursement program for education in medical field. Big organization offers some opportunities for professional development.
cons: It is a big organization and you are just a small part of the machinery and you can fill it.

pros:
Great benefits
good pay comparable or better than other places
nice offsite locations where you dont have to pay for parking
cons:
have to pay for parking at the main hospital, 75 a month
not much opportunity for advancement
not much communication between supervisors and staff

pros: There are a lot of opportunities within UW Health. Since there is a lot going on it is a good chance to explore different interests.
cons: Within this huge organization, it is easy to get lost in the mix. There is a lot going on 24/7 so communication between different departments is lacking, as well as communication between management.

review_title: not a bad place to work but...
pros: Good benefits, freindly people, world class serivice.
cons: Poor recognition of job well done, stagnet salaries, unfair raise system.

job_title: Registered Dietitian in Mount Horeb, WI
pros: Top of the line clinical care. Academic teaching environment with challenging and medically complex patients. Challenging place to work.
cons: Very political environment with horrible management. Employees are afraid of and do not trust management. Employees are afraid to come to work. Lots of favoritism. Career advancement based on favoritism rather than who is best qualified. Management singles out employees who they dislike and gives them extra work assignments and unfavorable schedules until employees quit.

job_title: Database Report Developer in Madison, WI
pros:
One of the main benefits was that everyone that worked there treated each other as humans. Politics was mostly non-existent within the group.

Very family friendly, and flexible working times.

Interesting challenges, and a great freedom for an individual to introduce new ideas and projects.
cons:
Salaries are a bit below market for the area.

Politics in dealing with physicians can sometimes become arduous.  

Little room in budget for any training beyond purchasing books.

pros: Good management, good work environment, good pay, care about their employees, top of the line interpreter services
cons: Nothing bad to say about U.W. Hospital & Clinics other than sometimes the interpreters doesn't have much time to travel from one clinic to another between appointments.

review_title: UWMF provides job security if health care is your career desire
pros: Offering decent health care benefits, paid time off/sick leave, and strong communication links, this company is a great work environment for health care driven individuals.
cons: In terms of some of the positions available, there is no room for upward growth or movement and new employees do not get to reap benefits of PTO until after six months of being hired.

pros: Great pay, great learning environment. Supportive company and management. Best place I ever worked. Always trying to improve.
cons: Parking is an issue. They will give you a free bus pass, but otherwise you have to be on a wait list and hope to pay around $1000 a year to park your car.

job_title: Attending Physiciam Infectios Diseases and Critical Care in Madison, WI

Superb leadership
Very efficient operations
Value employees
Transparency of policy making and admistration
cons:
Too little sharing of revenue between super-high earners and low earners who work very hard and are essential to the company's success
Top-heavy administatively
Overpay administrators

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Health benefits are very good, Wisconsin state pension available, regular pay increases (I have increased $1/hr in the first year), supportive management, paid time off, tuition reimbursement for select programs, opportunities to learn at work.
cons: Sometimes I feel like my experience and education isn't valued, especially by the doctors and nurses I work with. Overall, they're nice people, but sometimes I feel like I'll always just be a grunt to them.

review_title: Registered Nurse working in Pediatrics for 3 years
pros: Good benefits, opportunities to advance career, research hospital.
cons: No union, pay and benefits decreasing.  Upper management is disconnected from front line workers.

pros: Scheduling is flexible and tailored towards your academics. there are plenty of opportunities for you to learn about software and hardware.
cons: You have to be up to date and constantly reviewing  what you know. Given the nature of this job, its normal to research things on your own.

pros:
-Employees are very friendly and willing to answer any questions
-Lots of exposure to actual project management.  Even if I wasn't working on a certain project, I was able to attend project meetings to see how they are conducted
cons: Considerable amount of downtime without anything to be working on

pros: Great company, management makes you feel like you really matter. Employee development is very strong with classes and workshops.
cons: Some departments are understaffed for the current work load. There are some inequities between UW Hospital people and Medical foundation people in the area of benefits.

pros: Incredible learning facility with TOP neurosurgeons. Amazing professional respect, autonomy, and fabulously controlled environment thanks to the specialty ICU. 4-,  8-or 12-hour shifts or combo if you like. Amazing Nurse Manager.
cons: Stressful specialty because assessments are interpersonal and patients can turn on a dime - Q1hour neuro assessments so constantly interactive.

review_title: Superior Benefits, Caring Management, Excellent Patient Care
job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Madison, WI
pros: coworkers are wonderful in all departments, management engaged and receptive, everyone is here for the patients.  Benefits are one of a kind
cons: Changes in location and services can be expected, but the unknown is a little scary.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Flexible scheduling which was great for school and great supervising staff which were attentive and always there if I needed anything.
cons: One of the negatives is that the hospital is a very large place. If your coming from a smaller work environment the initial process can be quite daunting, but the organization does its best to accommodate.

pros: I feel as though I have a purpose. That I matter, that I'm appreciated. I may mess up but I'm not chastised, I learn and get  better at what I do, so I can help others better.
cons: non-union. And as in all places co-workers can be crude.

pros: High quality care, lots of medical services, Magnet designation.
cons: I often feel a lack of respect working as a Nursing Assistant at UW.  Very little recognition or appreciation for the work I do.  Mandatory overtime on occasion.

review_title: Large System with Plenty of Opportunity
pros: Lots of opportunity for mobility within the company and affiliates. Large network with strong infrastructure support systems. Fair compensation with decent benefits and accrued 'no-questions asked' time off.
cons: Confusing schism between the different 'branches' of UW Health system (different email, scheduling, and billing systems, etc.)

pros: Free parking at the 1102 S Park St location. Friendly coworkers.
cons: Management based on fear and intimidation.  Bathroom breaks, water breaks, etc are recorded and timed and then a report is compiled and sent out to all employees monthly. Also, the amount of money collected from patients is tracked and recorded and a report is submitted to managers of other clinics who forward it to their employees. This includes names of all employees and is ranked from highest percentage to lowest percentage collected.

job_title: Health Unit Coordinator in Madison, WI
pros: I loved the communication and the support I received from nursing it was all so wonderful.  Yes you will always have difficult coworkers but the organization itself was amazing.
cons: Wasn’t a fan of the parking.

job_title: Information Assistant Senior in Madison, WI
pros: Great benifit and care about family and patients. great for working mother.
cons: Managment and Supervisor need to work and comunicate with each other and  their employee. give more training and support.

pros: Nothing that comes to mind.  UW has a good football team.  Best place for management training if you have no formal education, B.S. Or M.S..
cons: Management is probably the worst in the industry.  Incompetinent CIO and all her crew.  With the new CEO nothing has changed, that should tell one what a state institution is all about.

pros: Exposure to all levels of the organization. Adept colleagues engaged in the mission of the organization.
cons: Restructuring after multiple organisation merger and the start of a new CEO. Leadership and strategic vision ambiguity. But this too shall pass.

job_title: Regional Services Coordinator in Madison, WI
pros: It is a place to work that has pretty decent benefits.
cons: The organization's management as a whole seems to not care about it's employees anymore. Pay is being cut. Benefits are being taken away. Good employees are being pushed out to make room for lower paid, newer candidates.
